glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.para: This page explains the different terms used in the Watcher system.
They are sorted in alphabetical order.

glossdiv.title: Action
glossdiv.para: An is what enables Watcher to transform the current state of a after an .
An is an atomic task which changes the current state of a target of the OpenStack such as:

listitem.para: Live migration of an instance from one compute node to another compute node with Nova
Changing the power level of a compute node (ACPI level, …)
Changing the current state of a compute node (enable or disable) with Nova

glossdiv.para: In most cases, an triggers some concrete commands on an existing OpenStack module (Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Ironic, etc.).
An has a life-cycle and its current state may be one of the following:

listitem.para: PENDING : the has not been executed yet by the
ONGOING : the is currently being processed by the
SUCCEEDED : the has been executed successfully
FAILED : an error occurred while trying to execute the
DELETED : the is still stored in the but is not returned any more through the Watcher APIs.
CANCELLED : the was in PENDING or ONGOING state and was cancelled by the

glossdiv.para: Some default implementations are provided, but it is possible to develop new implementations which are dynamically loaded by Watcher at launch time.

glossdiv.title: Action Plan
glossdiv.para: An specifies a flow of that should be executed in order to satisfy a given . It also contains an estimated alongside a set of .

An is generated by Watcher when an is successful which implies that the
which was used has found a to achieve the of this .
In the default implementation of Watcher, an action plan is composed of a list of successive (i.e., a Workflow of belonging to a unique branch).
However, Watcher provides abstract interfaces for many of its components, allowing other implementations to generate and handle more complex composed of two types of Action Item(s):

listitem.para: simple : atomic tasks, which means it can not be split into smaller tasks or commands from an OpenStack point of view.

composite Actions: which are composed of several simple
ordered in sequential and/or parallel flows.

glossdiv.para: An may be described using standard workflow model description formats such as Business Process Model and Notation 2.0 (BPMN 2.0) or Unified Modeling Language (UML).
To see the life-cycle and description of states, visit .

glossdiv.title: Administrator
glossdiv.para: The is any user who has admin access on the OpenStack cluster. This user is allowed to create new projects for tenants, create new users and assign roles to each user.
The usually has remote access to any host of the cluster in order to change the configuration and restart any OpenStack service, including Watcher.
In the context of Watcher, the is a role for users which allows them to run any Watcher commands, such as:

listitem.para: Create/Delete an
Launch an
Get the
Launch a recommended manually
Archive previous and

glossdiv.para: The is also allowed to modify any Watcher configuration files and to restart Watcher services.

glossdiv.title: Audit
glossdiv.para: In the Watcher system, an is a request for optimizing a .
The optimization is done in order to satisfy one on a given .
For each , the Watcher system generates an .
To see the life-cycle and description of an states, visit .

glossdiv.title: Audit Scope
glossdiv.para: An Audit Scope is a set of audited resources. Audit Scope should be defined in each Audit Template (which contains the Audit settings).

glossdiv.title: Audit Template
glossdiv.para: An may be launched several times with the same settings (, thresholds, …). Therefore it makes sense to save those settings in some sort of Audit preset object, which is known as an .
An contains at least the of the .
It may also contain some error handling settings indicating whether:

listitem.para: stops the entire operation
performs a rollback

glossdiv.para: and how many retries should be attempted before failure occurs (also the latter can be complex: for example the scenario in which there are many first-time failures on ultimately successful ).

Moreover, an may contain some settings related to the level of automation for the that will be generated by the . A flag will indicate whether the will be launched automatically or will need a manual confirmation from the .

glossdiv.title: Availability Zone
glossdiv.para: Please, read the official OpenStack definition of an Availability Zone.

glossdiv.title: Cluster
glossdiv.para: A is a set of physical machines which provide compute, storage and networking resources and are managed by the same OpenStack Controller node. A represents a set of resources that a cloud provider is able to offer to his/her .
A data center may contain several clusters.
The may be divided in one or several .

glossdiv.title: Cluster Data Model (CDM)
glossdiv.para: A (or CDM) is a logical representation of the current state and topology of the .

It is represented as a set of (which may be a simple tree or a flat list of key-value pairs) which enables Watcher to know the current relationships between the different ) of the during an and enables the to request information such as:

listitem.para: What compute nodes are in a given ?
What are hosted on a given compute node?
What is the current load of a compute node?
What is the current free memory of a compute node?
What is the network link between two compute nodes?
What is the available bandwidth on a given network link?
What is the current space available on a given virtual disk of a given ?
What is the current state of a given ?

glossdiv.para: In a word, this data model enables the to know:

listitem.para: the current topology of the
the current capacity for each
the current amount of used/free space for each
the current state of each

glossdiv.para: In the Watcher project, we aim at providing a some generic and basic for each , usable in the associated through a plugin-based mechanism which are called cluster data model collectors (or CDMCs). These CDMCs are responsible for loading and keeping up-to-date their associated CDM by listening to events and also periodically rebuilding themselves from the ground up. They are also directly accessible from the strategies classes. These CDMs are used to:

listitem.para: simplify the development of a new for a given when there already are some existing associated to the same
avoid duplicating the same code in several associated to the same
have a better consistency between the different for a given
avoid any strong coupling with any external (the proposed data model acts as a pivot data model)

glossdiv.para: There may be various proposed in Watcher helpers, each of them being adapted to achieving a given :

listitem.para: For example, for a which aims at optimizing the network the may need to know which are communicating together.
Whereas for a which aims at optimizing thermal and power conditions, the may need to know the location of each compute node in the racks and the location of each rack in the room.

glossdiv.para: Note however that a developer can use his/her own if the proposed data model does not fit his/her needs as long as the is able to produce a for the requested . For example, a developer could rely on the Nova Data Model to optimize some compute resources.

The may be persisted in any appropriate storage system (SQL database, NoSQL database, JSON file, XML File, In Memory Database, …). As of now, an in-memory model is built and maintained in the background in order to accelerate the execution of strategies.

glossdiv.title: Controller Node
glossdiv.para: A controller node is a machine that typically runs the following core OpenStack services:

listitem.para: Keystone: for identity and service management
Cinder scheduler: for volumes management
Glance controller: for image management
Neutron controller: for network management
Nova controller: for global compute resources management with services such as nova-scheduler, nova-conductor and nova-network.

glossdiv.para: In many configurations, Watcher will reside on a controller node even if it can potentially be hosted on a dedicated machine.

glossdiv.title: Compute node
glossdiv.para: Please, read the official OpenStack definition of a Compute Node.

glossdiv.title: Customer
glossdiv.para:
A is the person or company which subscribes to the cloud provider offering. A customer may have several
hosted on the same or dispatched on different clusters.

In the private cloud context, the are different groups within the same organization (different departments, project teams, branch offices and so on). Cloud infrastructure includes the ability to precisely track each customer’s service usage so that it can be charged back to them, or at least reported to them.

glossdiv.title: Goal
glossdiv.para: A is a human readable, observable and measurable end result having one objective to be achieved.
Here are some examples of :

listitem.para: minimize the energy consumption
minimize the number of compute nodes (consolidation)
balance the workload among compute nodes
minimize the license cost (some softwares have a licensing model which is based on the number of sockets or cores where the software is deployed)

find the most appropriate moment for a planned maintenance on a given group of host (which may be an entire availability zone): power supply replacement, cooling system replacement, hardware modification, …

glossdiv.title: Host Aggregate
glossdiv.para: Please, read the official OpenStack definition of a Host Aggregate.

glossdiv.title: Instance
glossdiv.para: A running virtual machine, or a virtual machine in a known state such as suspended, that can be used like a hardware server.

glossdiv.title: Managed resource
glossdiv.para: A is one instance of in a topology with particular properties and dependencies on other (relationships).
For example, a can be one virtual machine (i.e., an ) hosted on a and connected to another virtual machine through a network link (represented also as a in the ).

glossdiv.title: Managed resource type
glossdiv.para: A is a type of hardware or software element of the that the Watcher system can act on.
Here are some examples of :
It can be any of the the official list of available resource types defined in OpenStack for HEAT.

glossdiv.title: Efficacy Indicator
glossdiv.para: An efficacy indicator is a single value that gives an indication on how the produced by a given performed. These efficacy indicators are specific to a given and are usually used to compute the of the resulting .

In Watcher, these efficacy indicators are specified alongside the goal they relate to. When a strategy (which always relates to a goal) is executed, it produces a solution containing the efficacy indicators specified by the goal. This solution, which has been translated by the into an action plan, will see its indicators and global efficacy stored and would now be accessible through the .

glossdiv.title: Efficacy Specification
glossdiv.para: An efficacy specification is a contract that is associated to each that defines the various a strategy achieving the associated goal should provide within its . Indeed, each solution proposed by a strategy will be validated against this contract before calculating its .

glossdiv.title: Optimization Efficacy
glossdiv.para: The is the objective measure of how much of the has been achieved in respect with constraints and defined by the .
The way efficacy is evaluated will depend on the to achieve.
Of course, the efficacy will be relevant only as long as the is relevant (i.e., the current state of the has not changed in a way that a new would need to be launched).
For example, if the is to lower the energy consumption, the will be computed using several (KPIs):

listitem.para: the percentage of energy gain (which must be the highest possible)
the number of (which must be the lowest possible)
the number of virtual machine migrations (which must be the lowest possible)

glossdiv.para: All those indicators are computed within a given timeframe, which is the time taken to execute the whole .
The efficacy also enables the to objectively compare different for the same goal and same workload of the .

glossdiv.title: Project
glossdiv.para: represent the base unit of “ownership” in OpenStack, in that all in OpenStack should be owned by a specific . In OpenStack Identity, a must be owned by a specific domain.
Please, read the official OpenStack definition of a Project.

glossdiv.title: Scoring Engine
glossdiv.para: A is an executable that has a well-defined input, a well-defined output, and performs a purely mathematical task. That is, the calculation does not depend on the environment in which it is running - it would produce the same result anywhere.

Because there might be multiple algorithms used to build a particular data model (and therefore a scoring engine), the usage of scoring engine might vary. A metainfo field is supposed to contain any information which might be needed by the user of a given scoring engine.

glossdiv.title: SLA
glossdiv.para: means Service Level Agreement.
The resources are negotiated between the and the Cloud Provider in a contract.
Most of the time, this contract is composed of two documents:

listitem.para: : Service Level Agreement
: Service Level Objectives

glossdiv.para: Note that the is more general than the in the sense that the former specifies what service is to be provided, how it is supported, times, locations, costs, performance, and responsibilities of the parties involved while the focuses on more measurable characteristics such as availability, throughput, frequency, response time or quality.
You can also read the Wikipedia page for SLA which provides a good definition.

glossdiv.title: SLA violation
glossdiv.para: A happens when a defined with a given could not be respected by the cloud provider within the timeframe defined by the official contract document.

glossdiv.title: SLO
glossdiv.para: A Service Level Objective (SLO) is a key element of a between a service provider and a . SLOs are agreed as a means of measuring the performance of the Service Provider and are outlined as a way of avoiding disputes between the two parties based on misunderstanding.
You can also read the Wikipedia page for SLO which provides a good definition.

glossdiv.title: Solution
glossdiv.para: A is the result of execution of a (i.e., an algorithm). Each solution is composed of many pieces of information:

listitem.para: A set of generated by the strategy in order to achieve the of an associated .
A set of as defined by the associated goal
A which is computed by the associated goal using the aforementioned efficacy indicators.

glossdiv.para: A is different from an because it contains the non-scheduled list of which is produced by a . In other words, the list of Actions in a has not yet been re-ordered by the .
Note that some algorithms (i.e. ) may generate several . This gives rise to the problem of determining which should be applied.
Two approaches to dealing with this can be envisaged:

listitem.para: fully automated mode: only the with the highest ranking (i.e., the highest ) will be sent to the and translated into concrete .
manual mode: several are proposed to the with a detailed measurement of the estimated and he/she decides which one will be launched.

glossdiv.title: Strategy
glossdiv.para: A is an algorithm implementation which is able to find a for a given .
There may be several potential strategies which are able to achieve the same . This is why it is possible to configure which specific should be used for each goal.
Some strategies may provide better optimization results but may take more time to find an optimal .

glossdiv.title: Watcher Applier
glossdiv.para: This component is in charge of executing the built by the .
See: for more details on this component.

glossdiv.title: Watcher Database
glossdiv.para: This database stores all the Watcher domain objects which can be requested by the Watcher API or the Watcher CLI:

listitem.para: Audit templates
Audits
Action plans
Actions
Goals

glossdiv.para: The Watcher domain being here “optimization of some resources provided by an OpenStack system”.
See for more details on this component.

glossdiv.title: Watcher Decision Engine
glossdiv.para: This component is responsible for computing a set of potential optimization in order to fulfill the of an .
It first reads the parameters of the from the associated and knows the to achieve.
It then selects the most appropriate depending on how Watcher was configured for this .
The is then executed and generates a set of which are scheduled in time by the (i.e., it generates an ).
See for more details on this component.

glossdiv.title: Watcher Planner
glossdiv.para: The is part of the .
This module takes the set of generated by a and builds the design of a workflow which defines how-to schedule in time those different and for each what are the prerequisite conditions.

It is important to schedule in time in order to prevent overload of the while applying the . For example, it is important not to migrate too many instances at the same time in order to avoid a network congestion which may decrease the for .
It is also important to schedule in order to avoid security issues such as denial of service on core OpenStack services.
Some default implementations are provided, but it is possible to develop new implementations which are dynamically loaded by Watcher at launch time.
See for more details on this component.
